texts.definition: Diegetic elements of game worlds that have no gameplay enabled through them.
markups: <style="Definition">Diegetic elements of game worlds that have no gameplay enabled through them.</style>

Games with <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> rarely can let players interact in all conceivably possible ways with all objects they logically should contain, both for production reasons and for wanting to focus the gameplay towards certain activities. To still let the objects be present, this can be solved by having <style="CurrentLink">Props</style>, objects that cannot be interacted with or only have non-vital information connected to them.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

Trees are a common example of <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> found for example in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style> (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Crysis%20series">Crysis series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Just%20Cause%20series">Just Cause series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warcraft%20series">Warcraft series</link></style> are examples of games where the trees provide gameplay functionality).

Buildings that players cannot enter are another common type of <style="CurrentLink">Props</style>, often outnumbering the ones that can be entered for game worlds that include cities. Besides the games mentioned above regarding trees, games with this type of <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> include the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Grand%20Theft%20Auto%20series">Grand Theft Auto series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Assassin's%20Creed%20series">Assassin's Creed series</link></style> (here the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Just%20Cause%20series">Just Cause series</link></style> used <style="CurrentLink">Props</style>).

Backgrounds that provide the farthest one can see in game worlds can be seen as a type of <style="CurrentLink">Prop</style>. These are very common in 3D games (called skyboxes), found for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Crysis%20series">Crysis series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Deus%20Ex%20series">Deus Ex series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Halo%20series">Halo series</link></style>.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

As a pattern mostly related to diegetic and narration aspects, the most important design choices for <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> relate to these areas. While <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> do not have to exist inside <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, those that do naturally need to be given a location. <style="Link"><link="big-dumb-objects">Big Dumb Objects</link></style> are <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> and can therefore be used to instantiate the pattern in a game.

Even if <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> have no gameplay directly facilitated through them, they can affect gameplay in a couple of ways. They can affect <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style> by being designed to provide <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="landmarks">Landmarks</link></style>, or be <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style> that appear to be any of the former. They can of course also be <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> that block <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> and can be crashed into if diegetically plausible.  The use of them as large <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> provides an alternative to using <style="Link"><link="invisible-walls">Invisible Walls</link></style>. The can also be targets for <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Landscaping">Landscaping</link></style> goals, as for example done in certain <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ravenwood%20Fair">Ravenwood Fair</link></style> or what is required for animals to be satisfied in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zoo%20Tycoon%20series">Zoo Tycoon series</link></style>.

Unlike their use in theater and movies, <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> are rarely <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> that can be picked up or moved. This since this is gameplay activities and may affect gameplay-related aspects such as <style="Link"><link="inventories">Inventories</link></style>. It is however quite common to place temporary <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> where <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style> used to be recently to provide a smoother transition between their being and their not-being.

The <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> discussed so far exist only in computer-based <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, but <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> can also be physical. This is the common case in games with <style="Link"><link="live-action-roleplaying">Live Action Roleplaying</link></style>, but can also be found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> in the form of <style="Link"><link="player-aids">Player Aids</link></style>, for example <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Maps">Maps</link></style>. While <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Miniatures">Miniatures</link></style> may share several characteristics with these game components, they are not <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> since they have clear gameplay rules related to them in games. <style="Link"><link="feelies">Feelies</link></style> is the term used for physical <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> released together with some games, e.g. the map and booklet that came with later editions of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zork%20series">Zork I</link></style> and the syringe-looking pen that was part of the "Zombrex Edition" of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dead%20Rising%20series">Dead Rising 2</link></style>.
<style="H3">Diegetic Aspects</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Props</style> are often necessary for a game to be able to have <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>, the exception being <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> which are very sparsely populated with any type of objects. <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> may however easily ruin <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> if they look similar to game elements with gameplay functionality. This since in one case being able to use an object in a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> and in the second case not being able to use a similar object clearly points out an inconsistency in the game (See Linderoth & Bennerstedt 2007 for an example of crates and doors as both <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> and functional game elements). Even just becoming interested in a <style="CurrentLink">Prop</style> due to its appearance and then noticing that one cannot interact with in case produce the same problem. This makes using <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> a balancing act for game designers, one needs to have sufficient amounts of <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> in a game but they should draw attention to themselves. Even so, <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> can be designed to be <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> through their size, shape, or texture and this may be appropriate if they are supposed to function as <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="landmarks">Landmarks</link></style>.

Depending exactly on what they represent, <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> may need to be <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style> in order to maintain <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>.
<style="H3">Interface Aspects</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Props</style> typically have no interface aspects besides that they help define <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, and are rather defined as elements that do not provide interaction possibilities. The exception to this is when players can gain information by interacting with them, often through a simple click. In these cases the possibility is often indicated through presenting <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style> in conjunction with them, and so is often the information they provide as well.

In <style="Link"><link="live-action-roleplaying">Live Action Roleplaying</link></style> games, <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> can need to be very detailed to fit the <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> and thereby very time consuming to construct.
<style="H3">Narrative Aspects</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Props</style> can be used to create <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style> and add details and flavor to <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> can also work well as <style="Link"><link="macguffins">MacGuffins</link></style> since these do not need to have any functionality and in fact, little information needs to be revealed about them. Like <style="Link"><link="macguffins">MacGuffins</link></style>, they do actually not need to exist as physical entities in the parts of the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> players can act within - they can be present in games solely through <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style>.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Props</style> are ways of adding detail to <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> and thereby modulating them and possibly adding <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> through having more details as well as provide support for <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>. They do however instead break <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> when they are visually similar or identical to other <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>. When <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> are designed so they provide <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="landmarks">Landmarks</link></style>, they help <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style> (when they are <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style> they can of course instead make this harder).

While <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> cannot individually enable <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, they can modulate them or create them through being part of <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> can make <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> more interesting by providing variety, and when <style="CurrentLink">Props</style> exist as <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style> to things players wish to find they make <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> necessary.
